newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech cabinet to debate bank selloff on Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: Czech cabinet to debate bank selloff on Wednesday.

text.p: The Czech cabinet will discuss the privatisation of the country's four largest banks at its regular Wednesday session, but concrete decisions will probably not be taken, a government aide said on Tuesday.
"I think those will be rather framework decisions, some guidelines of privatisation, not concrete (decisions)," spokesman Ivo Strejcek told Reuters.

The state holds large stakes in the so called "Big Four" -- commercial bank Komercni Banka a.s., foreign trade bank Ceskoslovenska Obchodni Banka a.s. (CSOB), savings bank Ceska Sporitelna a.s., and IPB a.s..
The debate on the privatisation of the state holdings in the Big Four has gained momentum recently, but the government has yet to announce a plan.

Czech National Bank (CNB) governor Josef Tosovsky said earlier this month that there was broad consensus that the privatisation of the Big Four should go forward, only the methods and timing needed to be determined.
The finance ministry and the CNB have both said that the 31.5 percent state stake in IPB should be sold first.
Japan's Nomura and Dutch banks ING Bank NV and ABN AMRO Bank NV have been widely reported as expressing an interest in the IPB stake.

The CNB has submitted a plan to the cabinet proposing a merger of CSOB, where the state holds 66 percent, and Ceska Sporitelna where it has 45 percent, but Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus has reacted coolly to the idea.
The central bank plan also would not rush the privatisation of the state's 48.8 percent stake in Komercni, but would incrementally sell smaller stakes to various investors.
